greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest m such that a regular m-gon with all diagonals drawn contains a cell with n sides, or a(n) = -1 if no such m exists.
comment: Theorem: If n is odd then a(n) = n.
Proof. (i) If n is odd then the central cell in a regular n-gon with all diagonals drawn is a smaller regular n-gon. So if n is odd, then a(n) <= n.

(ii) Suppose a convex m-gon, not necessarily regular, with all diagonals drawn has a cell with e edges. Each edge when extended meets two vertices, so at most 2e vertices are involved in defining the boundary of that cell.
On the other hand no vertex can define more than two edges of the cell, so 2e <= 2m, so e <= m. So to get an n-sided cell, we need at least n vertices. So a(n) >= n. QED.
If a(20) > 0 it is greater than 385. - _Scott R. Shannon_, Mar 14 2021

example: Examining the images in A007678, for example Michael Rubinstein's illustration, or the images shown here, we see that the first occurrence of a five-sided cell is for m = 5, so a(5) = 5. The first time we see a four-sided cell is for m = 6, so a(4) = 6.
xref: See also A341729 and A341730 for the maximum number of sides in any cell.
results.author: _Scott R. Shannon_ and _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 06 2021.
